20101228002951.000|20101228002953.000|TR0|YELLIN:  Well, the death panel argument is 
20101228002953.000|20101228002956.000|TR0|back tonight, thanks to the "New York 
20101228002956.000|20101228002958.000|TR0|Times."  The White House is pushing back 
20101228002958.000|20101228003000.000|TR0|hard against yesterday's front page story, 
20101228003000.000|20101228003003.000|TR0|which said the Obama administration has 
20101228003003.000|20101228003005.000|TR0|quietly revived a part of the health care 
20101228003005.000|20101228003007.000|TR0|bill that was killed this year.
20101228003007.000|20101228003010.000|TR0|
20101228003010.000|20101228003012.000|TR0|It had to do with end of life planning for 
20101228003012.000|20101228003014.000|TR0|Medicare recipients, something opponents 
20101228003014.000|20101228003017.000|TR0|labeled death panels and reaction, White 
20101228003017.000|20101228003019.000|TR0|House officials are not mincing words.  
20101228003019.000|20101228003021.000|TR0|They put out a statement saying, quote, 
20101228003021.000|20101228003024.000|TR0|"the Times story is wrong.  This benefit 
20101228003024.000|20101228003026.000|TR0|was signed into law under President Bush."
20101228003026.000|20101228003028.000|TR0|
20101228003028.000|20101228003030.000|TR0|So, what's this really about?  I called 
20101228003030.000|20101228003033.000|TR0|over to the Department Of Health And Human 
20101228003033.000|20101228003035.000|TR0|Services to do a fact check.  Here is what 
20101228003035.000|20101228003037.000|TR0|I found. In 2003, when Congress passed the 
20101228003037.000|20101228003040.000|TR0|Medicare drug benefit, a little- noticed 
20101228003040.000|20101228003042.000|TR0|part of the law created a one-time 
20101228003042.000|20101228003044.000|TR0|wellness visit for new Medicare 
20101228003044.000|20101228003047.000|TR0|beneficiaries.
20101228003047.000|20101228003049.000|TR0|
20101228003049.000|20101228003051.000|TR0|In the visit, Medicare will pay for the 
20101228003051.000|20101228003054.000|TR0|doctor to do things like review your 
20101228003054.000|20101228003056.000|TR0|medications, see what tests you need, make 
20101228003056.000|20101228003058.000|TR0|a list of all your health care providers 
20101228003058.000|20101228003101.000|TR0|and even check your cholesterol.  Well in 
20101228003101.000|20101228003103.000|TR0|2008, Congress expanded those welcome to 
20101228003103.000|20101228003105.000|TR0|Medicare visits to also cover what's 
20101228003105.000|20101228003108.000|TR0|called end of life planning.
20101228003108.000|20101228003110.000|TR0|
20101228003110.000|20101228003112.000|TR0|It is counseling to help you make decision 
20101228003112.000|20101228003115.000|TR0|and issue directives about your health 
20101228003115.000|20101228003117.000|TR0|care in case you are eventually injured or 
20101228003117.000|20101228003119.000|TR0|too sick to function.  For example, if you 
20101228003119.000|20101228003122.000|TR0|want to be kept on life support if a 
20101228003122.000|20101228003124.000|TR0|stroke leaves you brain dead.  OK, this 
20101228003124.000|20101228003126.000|TR0|counseling is what the administration is 
20101228003126.000|20101228003129.000|TR0|referring to when they say President Bush 
20101228003129.000|20101228003131.000|TR0|first approved the benefit.
20101228003131.000|20101228003133.000|TR0|
20101228003133.000|20101228003136.000|TR0|So, what's different now, well, the health 
20101228003136.000|20101228003138.000|TR0|care reform law lets you do these wellness 
20101228003138.000|20101228003140.000|TR0|reviews every year instead of only one 
20101228003140.000|20101228003143.000|TR0|time, when you join Medicare and they are
